item.title: Regression
item.description: A process to analyse two sets of data and work backwards (hence the name) to deduce the relationship between the two sets of data.

item.title: Hypothesis testing
item.description: Refers to the process involved in accepting or rejecting statements about a population’s parameters. These parameters usually are the mean ($\mu$) or a proportion ($p$).

item.title: Estimation
item.description: The process of using a sample statistic to estimate the population parameter. The estimator is a statistic used to estimate a parameter, usually denoted with a capped symbol of the parameter; for instance, given parameter $\mu$, its estimator is denoted as $\hat\mu$.

item.title: Sampling
item.description: Refers to the process of extracting a subset of a population. Done either due to constraints around: time consumption; cost; feasibility; or impossibility.

item.title: Continuous probability distribution
item.description: A continuous probability distribution is the probability distribution of a continuous random variable. A common distribution is the normal distribution.

item.title: Number systems
item.description: A system of writing to express numbers. There are many number systems; among the most popular used in academics include:

item.title: Discrete probability distribution
item.description: A random variable can be discrete if it has: a finite number of values; or an infinite but countable number of values.

item.title: Combination
item.description: The arrangement of a given number of items without the consideration of order. Not to be confused with [[mathematics/permutation|permutations]], which is similar but with consideration of order.

item.title: Permutation
item.description: The arrangement of a given number of items in a particular order. Not to be confused with [[mathematics/combination|combinations]], which is similar but without consideration of order.

item.title: Probability
item.description: A branch of mathematics that examines the possibility of an event to happen. Events are assigned values between 0 (impossible) to 1 (always); many events in real life range in this spectrum.
